<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; non-affiliates and Purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates. </I>During the
second quarter and year-to-date 2005, sales for resale to non-affiliates increased primarily as a
result of new contracts with these customers effective in January&nbsp;2005 when compared to the
corresponding periods in 2004 which increased demand for energy by 88.2% and 73.6%, respectively.
The capacity component of these transactions increased $18.3&nbsp;million and $36.6&nbsp;million in the
second quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, over the same periods in 2004. Purchased power
expense &#150; non-affiliates decreased during the second quarter and year-to-date 2005 due to lower
demand resulting from the milder weather and Georgia Power&#146;s ability to utilize more economical
self-generation from base load resources. These expenses do not have a significant impact on
earnings since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel
cost recovery clause.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates and Purchased power expense &#150; affiliates. </I>Energy sales to and
purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These sales and
purchases are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions did not
have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is generally sold at marginal cost and
energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery
clause. Purchased power from affiliates during the second quarter and year-to-date 2005 when
compared to the same periods in 2004 reflects $12.8&nbsp;million and $30.4&nbsp;million, respectively, of
additional capacity expenses under PPAs with Southern Power that went into effect in June&nbsp;2004.
See Note 7 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Purchased Power Commitments&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other revenues</I>. Other revenues increased in the second quarter and year-to-date 2005 as
compared with the same periods in 2004 as a result of $1.7&nbsp;million and $3.2&nbsp;million, respectively,
of higher outdoor lighting revenues, $1.3&nbsp;million and $2.4&nbsp;million, respectively, of higher
customer fees that went into effect January&nbsp;2005, and $1.3&nbsp;million and $2.3&nbsp;million, respectively,
of higher transmission revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. Fuel expense increased in the second quarter and year-to-date 2005 primarily as
a result of an increase in the average cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour generated of 16.3% and
15.2%, respectively, when compared to the same periods in the prior year. These expenses do not
have a significant impact on earnings since fuel expenses are generally offset by fuel revenues
through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#150; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; and Note (J)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense. </I>Depreciation and amortization expense in the second
quarter and year-to-date 2005 compared to the same periods in the prior year increased primarily
due to the expiration in 2004 of certain provisions in Georgia Power&#146;s three-year retail rate plan
ending December&nbsp;31, 2004 (2001 Retail Rate Plan). In accordance with the 2001 Retail Rate Plan,
Georgia Power amortized an accelerated cost recovery liability as a credit to amortization expense
and recognized new Georgia PSC-certified purchased power costs in rates evenly over the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. This treatment resulted in a credit to amortization expense of $47
million and $94&nbsp;million, respectively, during the second quarter and year-to-date 2004. See Note 3
to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Allowance for equity funds used during construction</I>. The second quarter and year-to-date 2005
increases in AFUDC equity compared to the same periods in the prior year relate primarily to
construction of the McIntosh combined cycle units 10 and 11. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Plant McIntosh Construction Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for further information. AFUDC equity is non-taxable;
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">52
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">however, these increases are not expected to have a significant impact on Georgia Power&#146;s effective
tax rate for 2005.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>. The second quarter and year-to-date 2005
increases in interest expense, net of amounts capitalized relate primarily to the issuance of
additional senior notes since June&nbsp;2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net</I>. The second quarter and year-to-date 2005 increases in other
income (expense), net compared to the same periods in the prior year relate primarily to $4.5
million and $5.2&nbsp;million of revenue, respectively, from the flat bill pricing program and the
timing of the employee stock ownership plan contribution made in June&nbsp;2004 of $3.4&nbsp;million. The
2005 contribution is expected to occur in the third quarter.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Georgia Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Georgia Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Georgia Power&#146;s business of selling electricity.
These factors include Georgia Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment, to
achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to growing demand
and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future earnings in the near term will depend,
in part, upon growth in energy sales which is subject to a number of factors. These factors
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation
practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of
economic growth in Georgia Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these
issues, see BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. For additional
information, including information on certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March&nbsp;2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit accepted Georgia Power&#146;s petition
for review of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia&#146;s December&nbsp;15, 2004
order related to the Plant Wansley environmental litigation. Oral argument on that appeal has not
been scheduled. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein under &#147;Plant
Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; for additional information. The ultimate outcome of this matter
cannot now be determined.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Other Environmental Matters</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses sulfur
dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">53
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">matter National Ambient Air Quality Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the State of
Georgia, are subject to the fine particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth
within the rule. The rule may require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or
SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the installation of additional controls at Georgia Power&#146;s
facilities or through the purchase of allowances. The impact of this final rule on Georgia Power
will, however, depend on the outcome of legal challenges and development and implementation of
applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Georgia Power will depend on the outcome of legal challenges and
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA issued final rules addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;standards under the Regional Haze Program. States must develop regulations to implement the
federal regional haze requirements, including BART standards, by December&nbsp;17, 2007. The impact of
the final BART rules on Georgia Power will depend on the outcome of any litigation over the final
rules and the development and implementation of the applicable state regulations and therefore
cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;14 and 15, 2005, the EPA published final rules approving the redesignation of the
Atlanta metro area to &#147;attainment&#148; under the one-hour ground-level ozone standard.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia
PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring generation
market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern Company&#146;s
generation dominance within its retail service territory. Georgia Power has authorization from the
FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices. Georgia Power, through SCS as agent,
also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market rates. Specific FERC
approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an affiliate. On February
15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to generation dominance in its
retail service territory. On July&nbsp;8, 2005, the FERC initiated a hearing before an administrative
law judge to review the generation market power issues. Any new market-based rate transactions in
Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to
refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. In the
event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately applied, Georgia Power may be
required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail
service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The impact of such sales
through June&nbsp;30, 2005 is not material to Georgia Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this
matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power
and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, on May&nbsp;5, 2005, the FERC issued an order expanding the generation market power
proceeding initiated in December&nbsp;2004 to include an investigation of whether Southern Company
satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission market
power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a new
refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">54
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">and all new market-based rate transactions involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be
subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders lower rates beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005. The FERC also
directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending the outcome of the proceeding on
the IIC discussed below.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also, on May&nbsp;5, 2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is operated,
and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a party to the
IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to
utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just
and reasonable. In 2000, in connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized
Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code
of conduct. The FERC order directs that the administrative law judge who presided over the
McIntosh PPA proceeding be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the
testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate. See
Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Plant McIntosh Construction Project&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for further information on the McIntosh PPA proceeding. Effective July&nbsp;19,
2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be
subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC
Matters &#150; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc., as
counterparties to previously executed interconnection agreements with Georgia Power and another
Southern Company subsidiary, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the
agreements and that Georgia Power refund a total of $7.9&nbsp;million previously paid for
interconnection facilities, with interest. Georgia Power has opposed such relief, and the
proceedings are still pending. The impact of Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Georgia
Power and the final results of these matters cannot be determined at this time.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On May&nbsp;17, 2005, the Georgia PSC voted to allow Georgia Power to increase customer fuel rates to
recover estimated under-recovered fuel costs of approximately $508&nbsp;million as of May&nbsp;31, 2005 over
the period from June&nbsp;1, 2005 through May&nbsp;31, 2009, as well as future projected fuel costs based on
a June&nbsp;2005 through May&nbsp;2006 test period. The new fuel rate became effective June&nbsp;1, 2005 and
represents an average annual increase in</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">55
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">revenues of approximately 9.5%, or approximately $473&nbsp;million. Based on the order, a portion of
the under-recovered regulatory clause revenues was reclassified from current assets to deferred
charges and other assets on the balance sheet. At June&nbsp;30, 2005, Georgia Power&#146;s under-recovered
fuel costs totaled $516&nbsp;million, of which $363&nbsp;million is classified as deferred charges and other
assets. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K and Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Other Matters</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In
July&nbsp;2005, the U.S. Congress passed the Energy Policy Act of 2005
(Energy Act), which President Bush is expected to sign into law in
early August&nbsp;2005. Among other things, the Energy Act includes
various tax subsidies for electric utilities and provisions repealing
the PUHCA. The Energy Act also amends federal energy laws and
provides the FERC with new oversight responsibilities for the
electric utility industry. The implementation of the Energy Act
requires proceedings at the state level and the development of
regulations by the FERC, as well as other federal agencies. Georgia
Power is still reviewing the legislation; however, its impacts will
depend on the promulgation and implementation of final rules and
cannot be determined at this time.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Georgia Power cannot be predicted at
this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such
current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. Also see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of
Georgia Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation,
Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB Statement No.
123R. For Georgia Power, this statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2006. Although the
compensation expense calculation required under the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts
on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements are expected to be similar to the</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">56
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">pro forma disclosures included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Stock
Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Georgia Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December&nbsp;31,
2005. Georgia Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 47 on its balance sheet; however,
adoption is not currently expected to have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s income statement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Georgia Power adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material impact on
its financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at June&nbsp;30, 2005. Net cash flow from
operating activities totaled $357&nbsp;million for the year-to-date 2005, compared to $398&nbsp;million for
the same period in 2004. The decrease of $41&nbsp;million in 2005 is primarily the result of higher
fuel costs, which are recoverable in future periods and are reflected in the balance sheets as
under recovered regulatory clause revenues. During year-to-date 2005, gross property additions
were $408.1&nbsp;million. These additions were primarily related to the construction of Plant McIntosh
Units 10 and 11, transmission and distribution facilities, purchases of nuclear fuel, and purchases
of equipment to comply with environmental standards. The majority of funds for these additions and
other capital requirements were derived primarily from operating activities and financing
activities. See Georgia Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#150;</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Georgia Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements. Approximately $403&nbsp;million will
be required by June&nbsp;30, 2006 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past, including funds from operations and new security issuances. The
amount, type, and timing of any financings, if needed, will depend upon maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory
approval, prevailing market conditions, and other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for additional information.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At June&nbsp;30, 2005, Georgia Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets because of the
continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which can fluctuate
significantly due to the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Georgia Power had at
June&nbsp;30, 2005 approximately $9&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $780&nbsp;million of unused
credit arrangements with banks. Of these facilities, $70.4&nbsp;million expire in 2006, $350&nbsp;million
expire in 2007, and $360&nbsp;million expire in 2010. The facilities that expire in 2006 contain
provisions allowing two year term loans executable at expiration. Georgia Power expects to renew
its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. These unused credit arrangements provide
liquidity support to Georgia Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control
bonds and commercial paper. Georgia Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern
Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at
the request and for the benefit of Georgia Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At June
30, 2005, Georgia Power had approximately $380&nbsp;million of commercial paper and no extendible
commercial notes outstanding. Management believes that the need for working capital can be
adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large
cash balances.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB- or Baa3 or below. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At June&nbsp;30, 2005, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB- or
Baa3 rating were approximately $8&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at a
rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $246&nbsp;million. Georgia Power is also party to certain
derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for natural gas
price and interest rate risk management activities. At June&nbsp;30, 2005, Georgia Power had no
material exposure related to these agreements.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not
changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Georgia
Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in
the near term.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Georgia Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Georgia Power enters into fixed-price contracts for
the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Georgia Power has
also implemented a fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Georgia PSC.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">58
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY  &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Financing Activities</B></DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In January&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power issued $250&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;X 5.70% Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15,
2045. Proceeds from the sale were used to repay at maturity $250&nbsp;million principal amount of
Series&nbsp;L Floating Rate Senior Notes in February&nbsp;2005.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power incurred obligations in connection with the issuance of $85
million 4.75% pollution control revenue bonds. Proceeds from the sale were used to repay
obligations in connection with $85&nbsp;million of 5.40% pollution control revenue bonds in May&nbsp;2005.
Also in April, Georgia Power issued $125&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Y 5.80% Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2035.
Proceeds were used to repay a portion of Georgia Power&#146;s short-term indebtedness and for other
corporate purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also, in April&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power entered into an interest rate swap designed to mitigate its
exposure to adverse interest rate movements with respect to the anticipated Series&nbsp;Y Senior Note
issuance. In connection with the issuance of such senior notes, Georgia Power terminated the swap
at a fair value loss of $0.3&nbsp;million, which will be amortized over a 10-year period.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further, in April&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power converted the interest rate on $14&nbsp;million in pollution
control revenue bonds from one long-term interest rate to another long-term interest rate. The
conversion reduced the interest rate from 5.0% to 4.35%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2005, Georgia Power incurred obligations in connection with the issuance of $100
million 4.625% pollution control revenue bonds. Proceeds were held by the trustee and were used to
repay obligations in connection with $100&nbsp;million 5.25% pollution control revenue bonds in July
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first six months of 2005, Georgia Power entered into two derivative transactions to
reduce its exposure to interest rate risk. The transactions consisted of a $300&nbsp;million hedge of an
anticipated senior note issuance in 2007 and an interest rate swap on $300&nbsp;million of tax-exempt
pollution control bonds.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Georgia Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">60
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">65
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
</DIV>



<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF
POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="126"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">SECOND QUARTER 2005 vs. SECOND QUARTER 2004<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2005 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2004
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to customers within
its traditional service area located in northwest Florida and to wholesale customers in the
Southeast. Prices for electricity provided by Gulf Power to retail customers are set by the
Florida PSC. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business
of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to
growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators include
customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, and return on equity. For
additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; OVERVIEW -
&#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the second quarter and year-to-date
2005 was $21.5&nbsp;million and $36.1&nbsp;million, respectively, compared to $19.0&nbsp;million and $35.8
million, respectively, for the corresponding periods in 2004. Earnings in the second quarter and
year-to-date 2005 increased by $2.5&nbsp;million, or 12.9%, and $0.3&nbsp;million, or 0.7%, respectively,
primarily due to lower non-fuel operating expenses, excluding expenses related to Hurricane Ivan,
which are offset by revenues and do not affect earnings.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="52%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 8.3% increase in retail
revenues in the second quarter and 3.7% increase year-to-date 2005 when compared to the
corresponding periods in the prior year. Excluding revenues related to fuel and other cost
recovery, which do not affect net income, retail revenues were relatively flat for the second
quarter 2005 and decreased by $4.4&nbsp;million, or 1.2%, year-to-date 2005 as compared to the
corresponding periods in 2004. Retail energy sales for second quarter and year-to-date 2005 from
residential, commercial, and industrial customers remained mostly constant as compared to the same
periods in 2004. Other cost recovery for 2005 includes $6.5&nbsp;million of revenues related to the
recovery of
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power expense </I>&#151; <I>affiliates</I>. Revenues from sales
for resale to affiliates and purchases of energy from affiliates will vary depending on demand and
the availability and cost of generating resources at each company within the Southern Company
system. These affiliate sales and purchases are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by
the FERC. These transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues
through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism. The decrease in sales for resale to affiliates
and increased purchased power from affiliates in the second quarter 2005 is due to outages for Gulf
Power generating units which reduced availability. In addition, milder weather in the Southern
Company service territory reduced demand. The increase in sales for resale to affiliates for
year-to-date 2005 is primarily due to increased sales of available generation in the first quarter
2005 at a higher unit cost resulting from higher fuel prices.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the second quarter and year-to-date 2005, fuel expense was higher than the
same period in 2004 primarily due to an 11.6% increase in coal prices and a 14.0% increase in
natural gas prices year-to-date. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues
through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these expenses do not have a material impact on
net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense &#151; non-affiliates. </I>The decreases in the second quarter and
year-to-date 2005, as compared to the corresponding periods in 2004, are primarily the result of an
increase in available Southern Company system generation. Since energy expenses are generally
offset by revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these expenses do not have a
significant impact on net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense</I>. The increases in other operations expense during the second quarter
and year-to-date 2005, as compared to the same periods in 2004, are primarily due to expenses
related to Hurricane Ivan as approved by the Florida PSC. In April&nbsp;2005, Gulf Power began billing
retail customers approximately $2&nbsp;million monthly to recover these expenses. See Note (K)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under
&#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">67
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B></DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Gulf Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Gulf Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business of selling electricity.
These factors include Gulf Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve
energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to growing demand and
increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future earnings in the near term will depend, in
part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These factors include
weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation
practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of
economic growth in Gulf Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these issues,
see <FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS">BUSINESS </FONT>&#151; The SOUTHERN System<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For additional information, including information on
certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Gulf Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; and &#147;Environmental Remediation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses
sulfur dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the States of Georgia, Florida, and Mississippi,
are subject to the fine particulate and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the
rule. The rule may require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be
achieved by the installation of additional controls at Gulf Power&#146;s facilities or through the
purchase of allowances. The impact of this final rule on Gulf Power will, however, depend on the
outcome of legal challenges and development and implementation of applicable state regulations and
therefore cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market. The
impact of this final rule on Gulf Power will depend on the outcome of legal challenges and
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA issued final rules addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;standards under the Regional Haze Program. States must develop regulations to implement the
federal regional haze requirements, including BART standards, by December&nbsp;17, 2007. The impact of
the final BART rules on Gulf Power will depend on the outcome of any litigation over the final
rules and the development and implementation of the applicable state regulations and therefore
cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">68
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
 </DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B></DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151;</FONT> FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and
Florida PSC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Gulf Power has authorization from the
FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices. Gulf Power, through SCS as agent,
also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market rates. Specific FERC
approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an affiliate. On
February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to generation
dominance in its retail service territory. On July&nbsp;8, 2005, the FERC initiated a hearing before
an administrative law judge to review the generation market power issues. Any new market-based
rate transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27,
2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome
of the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, Gulf Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in
the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based
rates. The impact of such sales through June&nbsp;30, 2005 is not material to Gulf Power&#146;s net
income. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology
for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot
be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, on May&nbsp;5, 2005, the FERC issued an order expanding the generation market power
proceeding initiated in December&nbsp;2004 to include an investigation of whether Southern Company
satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission market
power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a new
refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any and all new market-based rate
transactions involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the
FERC orders lower rates beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005. The FERC also directed that this expanded
proceeding be held in abeyance pending the outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also on May&nbsp;5, 2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is operated,
and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a party to the
IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to
utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just
and reasonable. In 2000, in connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized
Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code
of conduct. The FERC order directs that the administrative law judge who presided over a previous
proceeding involving Southern Power, Georgia Power and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside
over the hearing in this proceeding and that the testimony and exhibits presented in that
proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate. Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from
transactions under the IIC involving
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">69

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
</DIV>




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B></DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">any Southern Company subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any
changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Florida PSC
Matters &#151; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc.,
as counterparties to previously executed interconnection agreements with any other Southern Company
subsidiary, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the agreements and
that the applicable Southern Company subsidiary refund amounts previously paid for interconnection
facilities, with interest. Gulf Power has also received similar requests from other entities
totaling $6.6&nbsp;million. Gulf Power has opposed such relief, and the proceedings are still pending.
The impact of Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Gulf Power and the final results of these
matters cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Hurricane Ivan (Ivan) hit Gulf Power&#146;s service territory in September&nbsp;2004. In March&nbsp;2005, the
Florida PSC approved a Stipulation and Settlement (Stipulation) between Gulf Power, the Office
of Public Counsel for the State of Florida, and the Florida Industrial Power Users Group which
allows Gulf Power to recover the retail portion of $51.7&nbsp;million, the projected reserve
deficiency, plus interest and revenue taxes from customers over a 24-month period beginning in
April&nbsp;2005. In connection with the Stipulation, Gulf Power has agreed that it will not seek any
additional increase in its base rates and charges to become effective on or before March&nbsp;1,
2007. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Florida
PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;10, 2005, Hurricane Dennis hit Gulf Power&#146;s service territory. Approximately 242,000,
or 60%, of Gulf Power&#146;s customers were without electrical service immediately after the hurricane
struck. More than 98% of those without power had service restored within six days. Based on
current projections, retail sales revenues lost as a result of power outages from Hurricane Dennis
are not expected to have a material impact on the net income of Gulf Power. Gulf Power maintains
an accumulated provision for property damage to cover the cost of damages from major storms and
other uninsured damages to its property. Due to the damages incurred in 2004 related to Ivan, the
accumulated reserve had a deficit balance of $42&nbsp;million at June&nbsp;30, 2005. The current preliminary
estimate of Hurricane Dennis restoration costs are approximately $60&nbsp;million. The established
policy of the Florida PSC, as recently reaffirmed by its decisions following the 2004 hurricane
experience of Florida&#146;s investor owned electric utilities, provides for recovery of these costs
through the mechanism of the property insurance reserve and, where necessary, through a special
recovery surcharge. In 2005, the Florida legislature authorized securitized financing as an
additional mechanism available to the Florida PSC and electric utilities in Florida for addressing
the extraordinary costs associated with hurricanes. Based upon the additional costs
related to Hurricane Dennis, this option, along with other alternatives, is being evaluated. See
Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">70


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B></DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2005, the
U.S. Congress passed the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (Energy
Act), which President Bush is expected to sign into law in early August&nbsp;2005. Among
other things, the Energy Act includes various tax subsidies for electric utilities
and provisions repealing the PUHCA. The Energy Act also amends federal energy laws
and provides the FERC with new oversight responsibilities for the electric utility
industry. The implementation of the Energy Act requires proceedings at the state
level and the development of regulations by the FERC, as well as other federal
agencies. Gulf Power is still reviewing the legislation; however, its impacts
will depend on the promulgation and implementation of final rules and cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at
this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such
current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various
contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. Also see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Gulf
Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation,
Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
instruments issued. In April&nbsp;2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB Statement No.
123R. For Gulf Power, this statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2006. Although the
compensation expense calculation required under the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts
on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements are expected to be similar to the pro forma disclosures
included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation requires that asset retirement obligations be
recorded when a legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are
conditional on a future event. For Gulf Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December&nbsp;31,
2005. Gulf Power is currently assessing the impact
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">71

<P><HR noshade><P>
